repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - GEF Protected Areas Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Global Environment
            Facility (GEF) Protected Areas Management Project (PAMP) for
            Pakistan were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to Global environment outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: establishing clear linkages
            between economic benefits and resource conservation. The
            benefits of long-term sustained economic resource flows from
            conservation such as through tourism and employment in
            Protected Area (PA) management were found to be essential to
            ensure sustainability in several conservation projects at
            the time, particularly in the India Eco development Project.
            Building understanding and consensus among stakeholders. A
            key lesson from other projects in the sector illustrated the
            need to build consensus among stakeholders on project
            objectives, activities and roles. Planning for long term
            sustainability. Providing start up funding, appropriate
            asset management arrangements and assessing the legal
            framework for the establishment of a trust fund were
            important lessons that had begun to appear in the sector. At
            the time of project preparation, conservation trust funds
            were beginning to take shape internationally. Experience
            with these funds highlighted the value of having reliable
            funding available during the initial stages of a trust fund
            to begin investing in activities before investment income
            becomes available. PAMP planned its activities around the
            notion of establishing a park association early in the
            project that would be capitalized with $2 million in seed
            funding. However, the association was established late in
            the project and the opportunity to bridge its beginnings
            until it was flush with investment income was squandered.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Protected Areas Management
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The report is the process framework for
            participation of custodial communities in park management,
            and conservation, and, addresses both environmental, and
            resettlement issues. While involuntary resettlement issues
            are not envisaged, restrictions on the access by surrounding
            communities to utilize resources, within the protected areas
            (PAs), will need to be introduced, to prevent further
            ecological degradation. Nonetheless, management practices,
            and alternative income generation measures will be agreed
            upon with those whose livelihood is affected by project
            implementation. By and large, communities in the PAs will be
            allowed to a continued grazing, and fuel-wood/timber
            extraction for subsistence needs, but under Park
            supervision. However, the introduction of culturally
            compatible, alternative livelihood measures (income
            generation), raises questions, namely regarding the Kalash
            group, whose goat rearing practices in high altitudes, of
            cultural significance, offsets possible restrictions in the
            utilization of high alpine pastures. Environmental
            mitigation addresses: biodiversity conservation, through
            committed, community involvement to specific, measurable
            actions; limiting the use of agrochemicals, or unnecessary
            construction activity; development of participatory
            fuel-wood impact assessments; management strategies for
            summer, and winter pasture uses; management of no-timber
            forest products, and of no illegal timber extraction; and,
            fisheries management, within the estuarine, and marine zone
            of the PAs.

repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - GEF Protected Areas Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The GEF Protected Areas Management
            Project aims at conserving globally important habitats, and
            species in three protected areas of Pakistan, within
            mountain, arid rangeland, estuarine, and marine ecosystems.
            The components include: 1) Protected area biodiversity
            management, through the following subcomponents: a) creation
            of a process framework for participation of custodial
            communities in park management, and conservation, through
            Village Conservation Committees; additionally, a technical
            assistance (TA) entity will provide planning, scientific,
            and social expertise. Community orientation, and
            mobilization will be provided, to map the community resource
            utilization, and develop resource management strategies, and
            mitigation measures; b) formulation of detailed park
            management, and strategy, integrated into community
            micro-planning, and micro-enterprise initiatives in
            accordance with environmental programs, and traditional
            ecological knowledge; c) improvement of park infrastructure;
            d) improvement of park operations; e) development of a
            baseline resource inventory, habitat improvement research,
            and wildlife enrichment; and, f) creation of public
            environmental awareness, and outreach programs. 2) Promotion
            of public/private cooperation for long-term biodiversity
            conservation, by providing TA, and supporting cost-sharing
            arrangements, and, income-generating activities. 3) Support
            an institutional capacity building training program, with
            topics ranging from legal, and policy reform, to tourism
            management, and plans. 4) Project coordination for the
            development of policy, and legislation relating to protected
            areas, ensuring standardized systems. Eco-tourism
            opportunities will be evaluated through the Tourism
            Development and Marketing Study.
